item.title: About me
item.description:
Short version

After a degree in IT and a Bachelor in languages, I am currently focusing on computational linguistics in a Master degree. For this reason, my skills are both practical and theoretical, namely programming, speaking other languages and use technology in everyday life. I also enjoy photography and therefore I learned by myself the basics of photo editing and I practice juggling in my spare time.

Long version

I was born the day 7 February 1996 in northern Italy.

Growing up I developed interest in technologies and in languages, so in my High School I choose the Information Technology career at the C. Zuccante institute, getting the diploma in 2015. After that, I decided to persue the passion for languages enrolling at Ca’ Foscari University of Venice to study Portuguese and Spanish, obtaining the degree in 2018. During my Bachelor I discovered the field of Linguistics, and I got extremely fascinated by that: I had no idea that there was a scientific way to study languages, actually, I didn’t know that there was science behind languages at all! But suddently, things got even better: thanks to some friends’ advices the area of computational linguistics came up, offering the chance to join my previous knowledge and interest for technologies with my new discovery. So here I am! Currently enrolled at University of Pisa to study a Master’s degree in Digital Humanities where I’m trying to specialize in computational linguistics doing exams such as Machine Learning, Human Language Technologies, Data Mining, Applied Linguistics.

I have the ability to use the personal computer to pursue my necessities, but I won’t lie, the majority of times the only thing I do is search a youtube tutorial regarding what I need! But after all, that’s what this age gives us: the possibility to learn stuff by yourself and help each other…My tought is, if somebody was able to do that, I can be able too!

Beside that, I am also a juggler in my “I don’t know what to do” moments and I like photography, but I never studied in detail these two things. Maybe, one day…
